title.narrative: Provision of emergency food assistance through vouchers to most vulnerable protracted IDPs in Mazar-e-Sharif

description.narrative:
The humanitarian situation in Afghanistan continues to steadily decline, characterized by the United Nations declaring that Afghanistan was a country at war in 2017, as well as Afghanistan becoming the deadliest conflict on earth in 2019 according to the Humanitarian Needs Overview (HNO) 2020. Approaching its 19th year of conflict, clashes between the Afghan National Army (backed by International Military Forces) and Armed Opposition Groups, continue to inflict high levels of civilian casualties and collateral damage on health and education facilities, as well as disrupting essential civilian infrastructures such as water, electricity and telecommunication systems, worsening the grave protection crisis and causing significant displacement. Additionally, lingering effects of the worst drought in decades (2018) accompanied by relentless natural disasters including floods, earthquakes, landslides and avalanches have exacerbated effects of the conflict, led to further displacement, and resulted in high multi-sector needs across the country. Populations are characterized by low resilience and high vulnerabilities and often fall into a state of acute emergency and need urgent support to meet their immediate basic needs. Within this context, food insecurity remains severe across Afghanistan, while the country is significantly affected by COVID-19. The socio-economic impact of COVID-19 is expected to have a devastating impact on people’s livelihoods. The lockdown and restrictions of mobility, will have a negative impact on both the supply chain for basic commodities as on the earning opportunities. Vulnerable people will be subjected to higher prices of food commodities, income losses, and experience reduced access to food due to supply chain disruptions and limited access to markets due to lockdown measures. Since the beginning of the outbreak of COVID-19, disrupted livelihoods and reduced income, coupled with chronic underlying poverty, have already started to further challenge families’ capacity to purchase essential food supplies. The city of Mazar-e-Sharif, as well as the whole province of Balkh, is specifically facing this worsening situation. The latest IPC analysis classifies Balkh as being currently as of April-May 2020 in Phase 3 (Crisis), and it is projected to have 40% of its urban population either in Phase 3 (Crisis) or 4 (Emergency). Through this project, ACTED will provide immediate life-saving food security assistance to 38,500 protracted IDPs (5,500 Households) in vulnerable employment status and facing significant decrease in purchasing power in Mazar-e-Sharif. ACTED will provide a full one-month food basket (6,500 AFN / 90 USD) through vouchers to most vulnerable beneficiaries who will redeem their vouchers against food items at local markets, with pre-identified shopkeepers.
In line with WHO recommended measures and MoPH’s official guidance, every activity implemented under the project will be strictly adapted in relation to COVID-19 context and mitigation measures and all staff involved will receive awareness sessions on COVID-19.

title.narrative: Emergency food assistance to meet the immediate needs of COVID-19 affected IDPs in Kandahar.

description.narrative:
With the proposed six-month project, DRC seeks to deliver one-month emergency food assistance to address the immediate food needs of COVID-19 affected IDPs in urban centers of Kandahar. DRC will target 6,642 vulnerable protracted households (HHs) with an average HH size of seven (46,494 individuals) as per the national average using cash as a modality. These HHs are characterized by unstable daily wage labor, and/or other informal or irregular sources of income that have been negatively affected amid government Covid-19 related restrictions, leading to worsened purchasing power and food insecurity. As per FSAC cluster guidelines (Jan 2020), the transfer value for cash for food is $90 USD per HH, representing a full food basket for a HH size of seven individuals. DRC assessment findings (HEAT Jan-Apr 2020) show that 89% beneficiaries indicate food as their first or second preference. This in addition to: COVID-19 mitigating measures such as reduced interaction with beneficiaries, FSPs and shopkeepers the many and scattered street vendors availability and prices of goods and food items and DRC’s extensive experience of conflict and culture sensitive cash and voucher programming in the South, deem cash for food to be the safest and flexible modality in target locations. The response is also informed by previous DRC experience and analysis of programming in Kandahar, showing that direct cash transfers as opposed to other modalities and e-transfers will warrant the access and inclusion of women. This will ensure beneficiary dignity and inclusion while supporting the local economy amid COVID-19. DRC has existing framework agreements with financial service providers (FSPs) in target locations ensuring timely and efficient response.
In addition to beneficiary preference for food assistance (HEAT Jan-Apr 2020), and a one-month cash for full food basket, target beneficiaries will be guided on the composition of the recommended food items, nutritional values and availability of the items in the local markets to encourage them to meet the intended food objective. Beneficiaries will be equipped with basic COVID-19 prevention knowledge including discerning rumors from facts, and advise to pace out purchasing of food to reduce market crowds as part of the pre-distribution process through awareness raising and key messaging.
Based on consultations with the Department of Refugees and Reintegration (DoRR), the FSAC cluster at the provincial levels as well as DRC IDP mapping, and identified response gaps, the selected locations are: Police Districts 5, 7 (Mirwais Mina), 9 (Loya Wala – right), 12 (Loya Wala – left) and 15 (Haji Arab/Salo Khan Chaman). Together these locations host an estimated 19,500 IDP HHs out of which 6,642 HHs will be assisted. Due to the fluid and fragile situation related to COVID-19, DRC would like to retain the possibility to modify the modality, locations and adjust budget accordingly, should local conditions substantially change as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic.
DRC will apply a targeted approach to identify vulnerable displaced population HHs in line with FSAC Vulnerability Criteria such as dependency ratio sources of livelihoods and nature of income – type, regularity lack of productive assets shelter condition presence of disability or chronic disease etc.). The project will be complemented through AHF-funded protection interventions to ensure vulnerable HHs facing protection concerns and risks (including people with specific needs - PSNs, women/child/elderly headed HHs) are identified during vulnerability assessments, protection monitoring and referred to other services (DRC and other actors). DRC will also consider individuals/HHs referred by other organizations as part of this intervention.

title.narrative: Food assistance to ensure the resilience of farmers with fragile livelihood status and to support vulnerable IDPs and recent returnees affected by COVID-19

description.narrative:
Afghanistan faced alarmingly high levels of food insecurity even before the COVID-19 pandemic, with an estimated 36 percent of the population facing severe acute food security and in need of urgent humanitarian assistance. The COVID-19 pandemic has turned from a public health emergency into a food and livelihoods crisis. Following the imposition of lockdowns in March-April 2020 and resulting reduction in economic activities, food assistance needs are particularly acute in urban areas where vulnerable households are increasingly impacted by a lack of livelihood opportunities, reduced purchasing power and increasing food prices. Households living in informal settlements and displacement sites, who have recently experienced additional shocks such as displacement and who lack employment are especially vulnerable, including IDPs and vulnerable returnees from neighbouring Iran. In rural areas, farmers and agricultural seasonal workers unable to cultivate and harvest have seen their livelihoods plummet and are in urgent need of food assistance during the current lean season.
In response to these needs, WFP plans to use this funding to provide unconditional, nutrition-sensitive emergency assistance to vulnerable households impacted by COVID-19 through two activities:
1. Food assistance for smallholder farmers during the lean season WFP will provide emergency food assistance to seasonally food-insecure smallholder farmers in 10 targeted districts of Herat, Nimroz and Farah provinces. The selected households were intended to receive agricultural assistance for cultivation from another partner (FAO). However, as this assistance could not be provided as planned, households depleted their existing food stocks to meet their basic food needs and thus require urgent assistance during the lean season. Households’ vulnerability has been compounded by the economic consequences of COVID-19 which have been particularly severe in the western regions of the country, including substantial rises in staple food items since mid-March 2020 (national average of wheat has increased by 15 percent, wheat flour by 15 to 21 percent, rice by 4 to 7 percent, cooking oil by 22 percent, pulses by 14 percent compared to 14 March 2020, according to WFP market price monitoring data as of 5 May 2020).
With this contribution, WFP will support smallholder farming households to meet their basic food and nutrition needs during the current lean season when food stocks and employment opportunities are reduced. WFP will purchase 654.8 mt of mixed fortified food to provide a one-off half-ration food distribution to 76,468 beneficiaries (10,924 households) in the targeted districts. Each household will receive a food basket comprised of wheat flour, vegetable oil, pulses and salt designed to partially meet their food needs for one month.
2. Cash-based transfers for IDPs and vulnerable recent returnees from Iran affected by COVID-19 WFP will provide cash-based transfers to 49,000 vulnerable IDPs and recent returnees (7,000 households) in IDP sites in Herat city who are in urgent need of assistance given the ongoing lockdown and resulting disruption to livelihood opportunities caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Targeted beneficiaries are located in the IDP sites of Shahrak Sabz, Shaidayee and Kahdistan. These already-vulnerable households face rapidly deteriorating food security as a result of the lockdown and resulting loss of livelihoods. With this contribution, WFP will specifically target households that have not yet received assistance from WFP or other partners to meet their basic food needs.
Each household will receive one transfer of 6,000 AFN (approximately US$78.43). This value has been endorsed by FSAC for COVID-affected households. Providing AFN 3,000 per month, this is equivalent to approximately half the FSAC-recommended basic food basket for a family of seven, and is designed to complement household resources to meet their food needs for two months

title.narrative: GBV and Child Protection Emergency Response during COVID-19 Pandemic in Afghanistan

description.narrative:
The proposed project locations Kabul, Herat, Kandahar and Nangarhar provinces are extremely vulnerable and exposed to high risk of COVID-19. GBV interventions will be implemented in Herat, and Child Protection interventions in Kabul, Kandahar, Nangarhar. As currently these locations are in the level of outbreak and having high number of positive Corona Virus cases, on other hand due to COVID 19 pandemic, recently more than 200,000 of people returned from Iran and Pakistan through Herat and Nangarhar bordering provinces. It is predicted that majority of COVID-19 positive cases came from these countries. As per Islamic Relief World (IRW) recent Need Assessment indicated that ongoing COVID -19 pandemic has significantly and quickly affected the context in these provinces. In which the children and women are more victim and exposed to risks in different forms such as violence, abuse, exploitation and neglect. Mental stress among children and women has been increased due to restriction in movement and stopping social activities.
The proposed project is focusing on provision of lifesaving assistance to 69,000 individual (men- 12,530, women- 15,560, boys- 19,750, girls- 21,160) in response to GBV and child protection in COVID-19 pandemic.
The project will disseminate mass awareness on GBV, Child Protection and COVID-19 through multiple channels i.e. FM radios, IEC and BCC materials using local in local languages (Dari and Pashto). The project will establish methods to regularly and safely share accurate, timely and actionable information in consultation with GBVSC and RCCE WG. During disseminating the messages through IEC and BCC materials, project team will apply different methods of communication i.e. one to one meeting, interactive session using IEC/BCC materials and examples etc to increase awareness and promote behavior change on GBV prevention and Child Protection as well as prevent community transmission of COVID-19. The project will engage key influencers i.e. Faith Leaders, Community Leaders, and Women Leaders to motivate people individually so that the awareness messages can be reached in the remote rural areas. 3500 women and girls will be provided culture appropriate dignity kits based on selection criteria to ensure their safety and dignity. GBVSC's standard items will be followed for the dignity kits. The project will assign Mobile Outreach teams for providing Psycho-social Support (PSS) for GBV survivors women and girls. The teams will interact with the women, girls and community members following local norms, values and align with need of women and girls. Serious GBV cases will be referred to the relevant service providing agencies. On the other hand, separate Mobile Outreach Teams will be visiting the communities and door to door for providing PSS counselling to the children at risk. Recreational materials and COVID-19 specific hygiene kits will be provided to 5000 children during the PPS sessions. 600 children at risk (separated from family) will be provided protection support through interim care, family tracking, reunification, services and case management.
IRW will closely work with GBV Sub-Cluster, CPiE Sub Cluster, RCCE WG, MoPH, district and provincial level government authorities and other NGOs to manage the response collectively and avoid duplication of works/beneficiary. All interventions of this project will be implemented with consideration of dignity, respect to the beneficiaries and their informed consent. IRW will also follow “Do No Harm” principle that guide to ensure beneficiaries security and safety in the project management cycles.

title.narrative: Provision of essential MHPSS and emergency health services in response to the COVID-19 in selected priority districts

title.narrative: To reduce further transmission of COVID-19 and reduce mortality and morbidity caused by severe acute malnutrition (SAM) in targeted high risk districts in context of COVID-19 in Afghanistan

description.narrative:
Health: Afghanistan remains a protracted complex emergency and is frequently affected by natural disasters leading to significant loss of lives, livelihoods as well as reversion of developmental gains. On 31 December 2019, a cluster of pneumonia of unknown etiology was reported in Wuhan City, Hubei Province of China. On 9 January 2020 Chinese authorities reported in the media that the cause of this viral pneumonia was initially identified as a new type of corona-virus. The situation has further affected when the local transmission moved globally with highest number of confirmed cases and deaths reported from Iran and Italy after China with multiple global hot spots. WHO expects that in the days and weeks ahead, we might see the number of cases, the number of deaths, and the number of affected countries climb even higher. On 11 March 2020, WHO declared COVID-19 a pandemic.
Afghanistan has been affected by the virus with having already the local transmission of COVID-19 with 33 out of 34 provinces already reported the cases. Slowing the transmission of COVID-19 and protecting communities requires participation of every member of at-risk and affected communities. It is therefore essential that national, and local authorities engage through participatory two-way communication efforts proactively, regularly, transparently and unambiguously with all affected and at-risk populations. Ability to engage and mobilize communities find, test, and isolate cases provide effective clinical care and maintain essential health services differs according to the capacity and context both nationally and regionally, as well as the intensity and prevalence of COVID-19 transmissions. Residents of high-density informal settlements find it especially hard or even impossible to comply with physical distancing measures and movement restrictions. The treatment of large volumes of patients with COVID-19 in existing health facilities is not possible, and widespread testing, contact tracing and quarantine measures may prove challenging without major, rapid and coordinated capacity strengthening.
There are nine priority areas that WHO plans to cover on the overall COVID-19 response. Under the AHF Reserve Allocation, the following two thematic health areas are covered: 1) Strengthen and enhance the capacity of national laboratories for sample collection and testing 2) Risk communication and community engagement
Nutrition: The Nutrition cluster has prioritized the activities as described in the COVID-19 Multi-Sector Country Plan. Strengthening the capacity of inpatient services is also part of the priorities. As of now, 26 high-risk districts are prioritized. These districts are also identified by DTM-IOM as high risks districts for COVID-19 on the Iranian border side. They are also HRP districts. The SAM cases with medical complicated need life-saving treatment services through inpatient facilities, which is in line of cluster HRP SO1 and CovId 19 Multi-Sectoral humanitarian country plan. The intervention will strengthen operational and staff’s functional capacity in the 24 IPD-SAM that provide treatment and care for children with complicated Severe Acute Malnutrition in the context of COVID-19 . Health workers in the targeted IPD-SAM will receive training on inpatient management of SAM, breastfeeding, hygiene as well as on infection prevention and control for the beneficiaries and health workers themselves. The targeted IPD-SAM will undergo assessment followed by functional upgrading, through the provision/replacement of F-75/F-100 milk preparation kits, which are essential in the management of the malnourished children. Equipment including medical equipment,medicine ,milk preparation kit, and cold chain and warming system, bed side chairs for caregivers will to ensuring the quality and efficient continuity of services provided by the IPD-SAM centers.

title.narrative: Emergency Lifesaving Nutrition support under CoVID-19 response in Herat and Badghis priority districts

The mothers will report on MUAC screening once a month, in addition to this the project strengthening the capacity of Family Health Action Groups, female volunteers and CHWs in Infant and Young Child Feeding to promote key IYCF practices and counselling based on the WHO guideline under the COVID-19 circumstances. This approach has potential to reduce the risk of rapid deterioration of the nutritional status of children with a MUAC result of 12.5-13.5 cm. title.narrative: Treatment and prevention of moderate acute malnutrition the provinces most affected by COVID-19 in Afghanistan.

description.narrative:
The COVID-19 pandemic is currently the most critical global concern with a potential for causing the highest mortality rates across the world in 2020. With limitations in the Afghanistan’s ability to fully control the transmission especially from populations moving into the country from the neighbouring states (Iran and Pakistan), it is anticipated that the spread will continue to provinces beyond those in the immigration/cross-border belt. Just like other countries, the scale and nature of the spread of COVID-19 has so far resulted into various actions such as border closures, internal and external movement restrictions, suspension and or closure of several socio-economic activities including schools. As a result, people are cut off from their normal livelihoods, access to basic services is significantly reduced causing a drastic deterioration of food and nutrition security. Most affected are individuals who are already malnourished while many at borderline food insecurity are at the highest risk of dropping into the food insecure category resulting into a higher likelihood of getting of malnourished. It is therefore anticipated that the rates of malnutrition will rise during this period.
As part of the response, and in line with the Nutrition cluster COVID-19 response plan and priorities, WFP plans to activate an emergency COVID-response that will aim at providing a malnutrition preventive safety net in the most affected locations. WFP will target the most vulnerable households with pregnant and breast-feeding women and children below 5 years of age in the highest risk COVID-19 districts and will provide unconditional nutrition assistance through a blanket supplementary feeding programme. The households in these districts will be identified with support of the WFP VAM team and in collaboration with other stakeholders. In addition, WFP will strengthen MAM treatment services in line with COVID-19 guideline on continuity for IMAM services. These will specifically be implemented in selected districts with the highest COVID-19 Burden. In these locations, in addition to static health facilities WFP will engage mobile health teams who will extend services to community level with the aim of preventing movement of clients but rather reaching out to them in much smaller groups that can be manged to adhere to COVID-19 prevention measures such as social distancing, use of personal protective equipment and sanitizing . WFP will further ensure that Nutrition assistance and related commodities are provided only once instead of twice a month to further minimize the potential spread of the virus through frequent contact. WFP will also try to ensure that through its cooperating partners, and in collaboration with MoPH, appropriate COVID-19 prevention messaging, hand sanitizing facilities and use of PPEs by service providers are applied and made available at distribution sites to protect both clients and service providers.
This proposal focuses on the procurement of specialized nutritious foods for treatment and prevention of moderate acute in children and PLW (Pregnant and Lactating Women) in the prioritized provinces and districts. With the US$ 1,028,622 from AHF 3rd Reserve Allocation WFP will procure 114 mt AchaMum, 193 mt Supercereal, and 74 mt WawaMum this quantity can cover MAM treatment needs for 12,600 children and 2,640 pregnant and lactating women in the 23 prioritized districts located in the 8 provinces of Farah, Ghor, Herat, Balkh, Badghis, Takhar, Kunduz and Faryab. In addition, about 16,381 children and 4,170 PLW will be reached with preventive nutrition support.
Upon funding approval using its Global Commodity Management Facility WFP will start SNF procurement to reduce lead time. Additionally, WFP may also draw commodity loans from other projects with some existing stocks to cover the needs in the targeted locations for the first 2 - 3 months as the other commodities are secured.

title.narrative: Delivery of lifesaving nutrition services to COVID-19 priority areas

description.narrative:
The global COVID-19 pandemic has led to immediate serious health concerns. The transmission of COVID-19 is expected to impact on all the conditions needed to sustain good nutrition – household food security, health and nutrition services and caring practices. On 11 March 2020, WHO declared the outbreak of COVID-19 a “pandemic”. Afghanistan confirmed its first case of COVID-19 in Herat province on 24 February 2020, and COVID-19 cases are increasing: to date, there are more than 2,700 confirmed cases in the country. Children and Pregnant amp Lactating Women (PLW) in the COVID-19 high risk districts are identified at a higher risk of acute malnutrition.
The Nutrition Cluster has identified 25 districts at high risk for COVID-19, within ten provinces (Farah, Ghor, Herat, Kunduz, Kabul, Faryab, Balkh, Badghis, Takhar, Nimroz) with pre-existing emergency levels of acute malnutrition, which would need continued provision of nutrition services.
UNICEF, the sole provider of Ready-To-Use-Therapeutic-Food (RUTF) in the country, forecasted a shortage of RUTF for the year 2020. To maintain the current scale of services in the target areas with an acceptable level of treatment coverage, UNICEF is seeking the support of the Afghanistan Humanitarian Fund (AHF) to support provision of lifesaving therapeutic supplies (RUTF) to secure Severe Acute Malnutrition (SAM) treatment services for a total of 20,856 children in the COVID-19 high risk districts.
UNICEF will procure the therapeutic supplies through its Supply Division. Supplies will be stored at national and regional UNICEF warehouses and will be distributed to the implementing partners (IPs) through Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) on a quarterly basis. The AHF project IPs are: Agency for Assistance and Development of Afghanistan (AADA), Bakhtar Development Network (BDN), Sanayee Development Organization (SDO), Association on Higher Education and Disability (AHEAD), Medical Management and Research Course for Afghans (MMRCA), Medical Refresher Courses for Afghans (MRCA), Coordination of Humanitarian Assistance (CHA) also the non-BPHS IPs including World Vision International (WVI), Save the Children International (SCI), and Action Against Hunger (AAH).
UNICEF will use complementary funding sources, including but not limited to the last AHF allocation, to provide therapeutic milk (F-75 and F-100 type) to complement the lifesaving treatment services addressing the needs of children with SAM with medical complications in hospitals in the 25 target districts in the 10 target provinces.
Outpatient and inpatient treatment of SAM are integral components of the Integrated Management of Acute Malnutrition (IMAM) approach, that will be delivered by the Basic Package of Health Services/ Essential Package of Hospital Services (BPHS/ EPHS) and humanitarian implementing partners through fixed health facilities and mobile teams.
Furthermore, SAM treatment will be provided simultaneously with the treatment of Moderate Acute Malnutrition (MAM) supported by World Food Programme (WFP), where applicable.

title.narrative: Improved mental health and psycho social well being of caregivers and children in Ghor province in response to conflict, disaster and COVID-19.

description.narrative:
Children in Afghanistan, especially those already suffering from poverty and inequity, are among the most vulnerable to the harsh socio-economic impacts of COVID-19. Child mortality, malnutrition, forced marriages, sexual abuse other forms of violence, exploitation, and child labor are all common challenges for the average child. With the addition of COVID-19 and its immediate and secondary impacts, children are now more anxious and worried than ever before and at greater risk of facing physical, sexual and emotional violence, especially as poverty rates and hunger in the country rise. A recent World Vision Assessment titled An Assessment of the Socio Economic Impact of COVID-19 on the Most Vulnerable Families in Afghanistan, has shown that almost 50% of caregivers are suffering from negative psychosocial symptoms due to COVID-19 and 30% of children expressed feelings of sadness related to the pandemic. To mitigate negative coping mechanism and enhance the psychosocial wellbeing of children and caregivers, delivery of specialized MHPSS services, as well as an effective case management system is essential.
In order to ensure sustainability and the capacity of existing community structures is strengthened, WV will focus on working with already formed Faith Leader Forums that comprises of community and faith leaders in Firozkoh, Dowlat yar and Lal Serjangal. In addition, WV will support CPAN with essential capacities related to enhancing the protective environment for boys and girls. The community based approach will include contextualized ToT trainings on PSS, Child Safeguarding and Positive Coping Mechanisms as well as ongoing support in order to empower community leaders and CPAN to have ownership of the program. A specialized MHPSS response will be delivered through awareness sessions and home to home visits, to ensure the most vulnerable caregivers, boys and girls have the opportunity to engage in PSS activities plus receive useful age and gender appropriate information to adopt positive coping mechanisms. Community engagement and risk communications will adhere to guidance shared by the RCCE Working Group.
The COVID-19 pandemic has exacerbated pre-existing vulnerabilities and further limited access to life-saving services, including case management. The disruption in the environment, socio-economic situation, daily routines and life of the families and communities and the measures put in place to prevent and control the spread of COVID19 heavily affects children’s development and well-being. Case management is an essential service which children must have access to in order to ensure they receive the support and services required while they are at heightened risk of abuse, neglect, and exploitation. WV will assess and strengthen the case management system across Ghor province, to support the service delivery of CPAN and other CP actors to deliver a coordinated and effective case management service, based on lessons learnt, best practice and guiding principles.
Building on established structures, WV will support a total of 4 existing Mobile Health and Nutrition Teams (MHNT) in 3 districts of Ghor. Currently, WV has 2 MHNTs in Firozkoh, 1 MHNT in Dowlat yar, and 1 MHNT in Lal Serjangal. MHNTs provide awareness raising, counseling, treatment, and referrals for mental health and psychosocial disorders using the mhGAP and ISAC guidelines for mental health in emergencies. In addition, WV is currently programming a COVID-19 response in Firozkoh using a community-based approach to mitigate risks and enhance the protective environment of populations. All PSS activities in the project will adhere to the Global Protection Cluster’s Guidelines for Restarting PSS Activities in an Emergency Setting.

title.narrative: Support to vulnerable households through distribution of cash for protection in Afghanistan

description.narrative: UNHCR will distribute cash assistance AFN 15,500 (approx. USD 195 per family) to 1,400 protection-vulnerable households among IDPs, returnees and host communities impacted by COVID-19 in Afghanistan. This is in response to the needs outlined in section 1 which shows the precarious protection situation of the people in Afghanistan due to COVID-19, exacerbating the already difficult social and economic conditions. Beneficiaries will be selected using existing data. Over the past three years, UNHCR has conducted in-person vulnerability/needs assessments for persons of concern for different cash-based programmes including cash for shelter, support to persons with specific needs, winterization, among others. The vulnerability profile of these former cash recipients is consolidated and maintained by UNHCR. Given the current circumstances where in person or household visits are not feasible, beneficiaries will primarily be selected through a desk review followed by data validation. In identifying the target group for this activity, UNHCR analyzed this data and pre-selected those who met the categorical selection criteria for a phone-based validation interview (conducted by a partner) to verify their basic biodata and presence in the country. The validation of the beneficiary details is carried out by Women for Afghan Women (WAW), Coordination of Humanitarian Assistance (CHA), Organization of Human Welfare (OHW) and BEST, all of whom have existing partnership agreements with UNHCR. The AHF-funded activity will be incorporated into the work of the UNHCR sub offices and staff to ensure the implementation All households with specific profiles were scored as per the categorical selection criteria. Households were assigned a score of one (1) for each risk/vulnerability profile one (1) for not receiving any assistance. Each household’s score was aggregated and ranked in order of priority. This modality was due to limitations in conducting face-to-face interviews, related efficiencies in utilizing existing data and avoiding respondent fatigue, good practices in targeting approaches during pandemics, and existing literature on groups most impacted by COVID-19. The cash is delivered by a Money Service Provider (MSP). UNHCR has ongoing cash-based programmes targeted for a cross-section of populations-in-need and existing distribution sites across the country, with COVID-19 specific mitigation measures, will be utilized. Transmission of COVID-19 at distribution sites is mitigated by several actions ex: distributing cash in secure locations, organizing distribution into smaller distributions over several days, distributing cash in envelops, provision of facilities for handwashing and wearing PPE. UNHCR is responsible for disseminating information on the amounts, frequency, distribution points, dates and times for payments through phone calls and existing community leadership structures. UNHCR staff will be present during the distribution. Should the security situation and other restrictions limit UNHCR staff from being present during the distributions, the same will be monitored remotely by phone, and partner staff will be physically be present to witness the distribution. During the distribution, when cash is handed out, the recipient will be provided a brief awareness session including information regarding the complaints mechanism. Please refer to section 6 for more details. UNHCR has mobilized community support and involved local authorities in the design and delivery of the programme. This ensures adequate understanding of the programme as well as necessary measures are in place to safeguard both programme recipients and humanitarian staff. UNHCR also utilizes secure distribution sites to deliver the cash assistance to beneficiaries. Moreover, complaint mechanisms are in place to continuously raise awareness of the programme to both recipients and non-recipients, and to review any valid comments or concerns, before escalating to conflict.

title.narrative: Supporting vulnerable girls and boys regain access to education due to COVID-19-related school closures in Jawzjan, Afghanistan.

description.narrative:
Since March 2020, due to COVID-19, Afghanistan has closed its schools for five months leaving 7.5 million children with no access to education. Alternative modalities were put in place to provide education to children, including distance education (through television, radio), self-learning and small group learning but these relied heavily on access to electricity and/or technology, leaving the most vulnerable behind. With the rate of new cases decreasing, the Ministry of Education has started to allow schools to reopen as long as they meet minimum requirements to allow a safe return to learning, including comprehensive protocols and strict hygiene measures to prevent the transmission of COVID- 19. In response to this, ACTED will provide support to 80 schools and 13 CBCs in Mingajik, Aqcha and Fayzabad districts of Jawzjan, reaching 43,174 women, men, boys and girls.
The response will provide 58 primary and secondary schools and 13 CBCs with access to handwashing stations with soap and potable water plus WASH and disinfection kits. In addition, ACTED will provide 43,174 boy and girl students, women and men teachers with two washable, reusable facemasks each across 80 schools and 13 CBCs.
As CBE and schools are unlikely to be able to open straightaway in every case, ACTED will also provide 5,736 vulnerable Grade 1-3 children with self-learning materials so they are able to regain access to education as quickly as possible.

title.narrative: Life-saving winterization support for 1,060 vulnerable families affected by extreme climatic conditions in Daykundi province.

description.narrative:
According to the most recent Joint Winterization Strategy – 2020, 101,603 people in Daykundi province require multi-sectoral assistance to cope with the next winter season. Harsh climatic conditions, and projected heavy snowfalls due to the high altitude, will disproportionally affect heavily indebted target communities, facing lack of job opportunities and selling off their assets to meet their basic needs. Huge loss of productive assets such as agricultural land, agricultural inputs, and livestock due to natural disasters and poor economic climate have severely affected the wellbeing of the target population. The COVID-19 pandemic (C-19) has eroded communities’ already limited capacities and acquired resilience to face extreme weather conditions. Additionally, emergency levels of food insecurity (IPC 4) recorded in the province are unlikely to improve in the next 4 months. Small-holder farmers are soon to see their food stocks exhausted, faced with the necessity of adopting negative coping strategies to survive the winter months. Based on findings from its recent needs assessment, RCDC and Caritas Germany (CG) propose to provide 1,060 households (8,480 individuals) with critical winterization life-saving assistance.
Partners have envisaged a multi-sector approach, in line with the Joint Winterization Strategy – 2020 priorities and standardized assistance packages. Assistance has been customized according to needs assessment findings on a geographical base.
In line with ESampNFIs cluster priorities, CG and its two sub-implementing partners RCDC and CAWC propose to provide 800 households in Sharestan and Miramor districts with in-kind blankets and quilts (value of 40USD) aimed at meeting household winter priorities. Among rural communities of Sharestan and Miramor districts, an additional livestock protection package will be provided in-kind to the same 800 households. While in Nili city, the need for heating material/devices has been prioritized through the provision of a standard cash package of 260USD to 260 households, complemented by in-kind blanket support. Additionally, due to the lack of job opportunities, which will aggravate during winter, the same beneficiaries will also be supported with a subsidiary rental package (75USD). As complementary assistance, all 1,060 households receiving ESampNFI support will also receive standard food security support in the form of cash (3,000AFN).
Cash assistance has been envisaged as unconditional and unrestricted, with the sole exception for the rental subsidy package which will be provided only to households currently living in a rented accommodation. The decision has been based on results from REACH Winterization Evaluation 2019-2020, as well as assistance preferences for unconditional, one-off cash assistance mentioned by target population. Furthermore, cash assistance will be carried out through the Hawala system, identified as the most viable and widely spread solution by partners’ a.m. Feasibility Study.
The present response priorities are in line with partners’ past experience and capability, and represent a scale up of current relief activities in the target area. Partners’ current interventions focus on livelihood enhancement with a focus on natural resources utilization and response to shocks increased access to savings and investments for business development. Thus, the action aims at enlarging partners’ reach by supporting vulnerable households with winter prepositioning assistance.

title.narrative: Integrated Winterisation, Food, and Protection Assistance for Acutely Vulnerable Host Populations of Badakhshan Province

description.narrative:
In the wake of the COVID-19 crisis, an estimated 90 percent of the Afghan population is now living below the poverty line (MoE). Given the severe economic impact of the virus, combined with protracted conflict, widespread food insecurity, and a multitude of pre-existing needs, households remain unprotected and unprepared for the upcoming winter season. Accordingly, Concern Worldwide is proposing an integrated cluster response entailing joint winterisation and food assistance, shelter insulation, and protection support for the most at risk host populations of Badakhshan Province in preparation for the harsh winter season. The project’s target districts―Yawan, Kohistan, Raghistan, Jorm, Warduj and Shahr-e-Buzurg of Badakhshan Province―were identified based on severe winterisation needs attributed to critical climatic conditions (altitude, temperature, and weather), prevalent IPC 4 levels of food insecurity, remoteness and associated lack of humanitarian assistance, and susceptibility to shocks. The action promotes inter-cluster linkages with the aim of improving the quality and efficiency of assistance by breaking down sectoral barriers and applying a more holistic approach to winterisation assistance.
Specifically, Concern will respond to the critical seasonal needs of 1,000 acutely vulnerable families in Yawan, Raghistan, Kohistan, and Shahr-e-Buzurg districts with an integrated package of i) 3-month heating/fuel cash assistance ($200) ii) blankets and quilts (in-kind, $40 value) and iii) 2-month food support (in-kind, $180 value). This combined package draws on lessons learnt from the 2019 Afghanistan Winterisation Strategy and recent PDM findings, with the aim of reducing the incentive to sell-off winterisation assistance to purchase food by jointly addressing the prioritised winterisation needs reported by affected populations last year. While this support is intended to be distributed jointly, households that do not meet the criteria for all three packages will only receive the relevant assistance. Concern will scale-up its current shelter project under the AHF First Standard Allocation of 2020 and respond to the urgent shelter and protection needs of 107 conflict-affected households residing in partially damaged shelters in Jorm and Warduj districts through the provision of in-kind Emergency Shelter Toolkits ($60 value) alongside Shelter Upgrade or Repair support via two conditional cash instalments (totalling $300). On-site technical guidance and monitoring will be integrated throughout project implementation to ensure that repairs are inclusive and implemented according to plan and quality benchmarks. To mitigate or address protection concerns resulting from the winter season and pre-existing needs, Concern will provide dignity kits (in-kind, $28 value) consisting of female hygiene and sanitary items to 210 female-headed households receiving ESNFI and/or food support.
Throughout project implementation, Concern will mainstream COVID-19 risk communication and awareness campaigns―including hygiene promotion within winter sectorial response―as well as gender-sensitive behavioural change messaging to positively influence expenditure choices, food practices, and coping strategies. Gender, age, and disability considerations will be carefully integrated to ensure the response is inclusive to all segments of a community, particularly People with Specific Needs (PSNs). As women are significantly less likely to report problems with their assistance, Concern will conduct sensitisation tailored to female beneficiary groups to encourage feedback into meaningful access and appropriate modalities for support. With over two decades of operational presence in Badakhshan, Concern is incredibly well positioned to provide trusted, rapid humanitarian assistance informed by last year’s winter response that will enable acutely vulnerable families to prepare and recover from the winter season with greater resilience.

title.narrative: Winterization Response Assistance to HHs, affected by the conflict and natural disaster in Nuristan province of Afghanistan

description.narrative:

In addition, it will decrease child labor as children do not have to go out in the harsh winter to collect firewood lessening the prevalence of respiratory tract diseases. Research has shown that vulnerable households increase their debt during winter months, and it is especially difficult for elderly, child, or female HHHs to repay these debts after the winter season. An appropriate coordinated response provides necessary protection assistance to affected communities and people, including children, in a timely manner. The first SO1 is entirely focused on the winterization however Covid-19 awareness-raising will take place during both cash distributions. SO2 focusses on Protection issues addressing the prevalence of GBV, DV, child marriages, and child labor.
The intervention will be through unrestricted and unconditional cash distribution. To reduce the risk that cash is used for unintended purposes, beneficiaries are informed and cash is labeled and distributed in 2 installments of each USD 130 to provide firewood for 3-4 months. This modality is chosen as it empowers beneficiaries to have more control over their own resources which will maintain their dignity as they have a choice. The market in Parun, the capital of Nuristan, is able to deal with the demand for firewood for heating. The district Wama is closer to the Dara-e-pech district of Kunar with a market at Nangalam city able to serve the people of Wama district. The market is located on the intersection point of these districts. Wama also has its own district market with sufficient capacity to provide heating materials such as wood, heaters, shoes, etc. The markets are accessible on foot, donkey, and the occasional car. Donkeys carry the wood. The communities are stable hence social cohesion is reasonably strong through which community members support each other, in particular the elderly, people with disabilities, and female-headed households. 957 Households in Nuristan will receive a winterization package which is fuel (in cash). 657 HHs from Parun and 300 HHs from Wama district will be chosen. Both markets will be able to handle this # of beneficiaries. A proven Hawala and his team will visit Parun and Wama and if the distance to travel for the beneficiaries will be more than 1 hour, the Hawala will travel to those villages. The distribution will be done based on the signed lists and/or tokens issued to the selected beneficiaries by the BSC, phone numbers will be collected in order to reference and NIDs checked. The Covid-19 prevention kits will be conditional to encourage partitioning Covid-19 and Protection awareness-raising sessions. Key people of each village participate in community dialogues in order to discuss protection issues. Due to the short project duration information will be shared about other services available within the area to enable women to potentially get in touch with support services.

title.narrative: Provision of winterization assistance to vulnerable households in Ferozkoh district of Ghor province

description.narrative:
According to the Joint Winterization Strategy (dated July 2020), 799,000 people in Ghor will be exposed to harsh winter weather in the coming winter season. Local communities already experience the devastating effects of the Covid-19 pandemic, which has led to widespread illness and mortality, a deep economic recession, and starkly reduced income opportunities. The pandemic has depleted productive assets and reduced communities’ capacity to cope with shocks. This situation is expected to continue through 2020, as vulnerable households are exposed to further shocks including loss of employment, reduced income, and rising prices over the lean season. Afghanaid’s needs assessment (attached as Annex A), conducted in September 2020 in Ferozkoh district of Ghor, found that the vast majority of households in the district are unable to cover their basic needs and resort to negative coping strategies. In response to this crisis, Afghanaid proposes to provide 300 IDP households in Ferozkoh with lifesaving shelter assistance and a total of 1,300 households with critical heating assistance. Based on a unanimous community preference for cash transfers and a recent market assessment (attached as Annex B) confirming community access to well-functioning markets, Afghanaid proposes cash as the assistance modality.
In line with Emergency Shelter and Non-Food Items Cluster priorities as detailed in the Joint Winterization Strategy, Afghanaid proposes to provide 300 vulnerable households in Ferozkoh district with a standard rent assistance package for three months, or US$225 per household. Those same households and 1000 additional households (500 IDP and 500 host community) will receive a standard heating assistance package for 4 months through a cash transfer of US$260 per household. A beneficiary selection and distribution committee will be established which will include representatives from local communities (e.g. CDC and DDA heads), Government departments (e.g. ANDMA and DoRR), IoM and Afghanaid staff. Beneficiaries will be selected according to ESNFI vulnerability criteria to ensure the most acutely in need and vulnerable are targeted, including displaced people, women-headed households and households with a large number of dependent children.
To carry out the cash distribution, contracts will be established with a reliable saraf. The cash will then be distributed at central distribution points in two tranches. Rent assistance recipients will be required to present a copy of their rental agreement, or will be supported to set up a rental contract where such a document is not yet in place. They will receive US$75 as a first tranche, and after submission of their rental invoice, the second tranche of US$150. title.narrative: Emergency Food Assistance to communities affected by COVID-19 in Kot and Batikot Districts of Nangarhar.

description.narrative: In line with the priorities of the AHF 5th Reserve Allocation 2020, revised HRP 2018-2021 SO1 (lives are saved in areas of highest needs), and FSAC outcome 1.3 (shock affected people (IDPs, returnees, refugees, natural disaster affected, people affected by COVID-19 and seasonaly food insecure IPC phase 3 and 4 people) of all ages have a minimum household food consumption score of above 42.5), Cordaid and partner RRAA propose cash for food to 2,620 HH (18,339 people) from communities disproportionately affected by COVID-19 in Kot and Batikot districts of Nangarhar. Cordaid will leverage the requested AHF grant with US$29,300, enabling Cordaid to cover 320 additional HH (2,300 HH covered by AHF grant and 320 HH by Cordaid private funds). The target beneficiaries are those who have experienced multiple resilience eroding shock in the past 6 months, and those subject to recent COVID-19 pressures, including lack of employment. They will receive cash for food. Following FSAC guidelines, assistance is half a food basket for a period of 2 months (US$90 in local currency) distributed in one instalment. The proposed unconditional cash assistance ensures continued, regular access to food for acute food insecure people in Kot and Batikot where people were already severely acute food insecure prior to the pandemic, but their situation has worsened by COVID-19 The proposed response is designed based on needs and gaps identified by the FSAC and 5th reserve allocation, and confirmed by recent assessments (annex A): 83% of the respondents have a poor food consumption score, 82% is applying high coping strategies. To address the acute food needs Cordaid proposes cash distribution to complement existing food stocks. Cordaid ensures that the most vulnerable people are included in the assistance, with a focus on female headed HH, HH with PWD and or where the primary breadwinner has lost employment due to COVID-19, as unemployment in the target areas is very high (71%). Beneficiary Selection Committees (BSC) will be established, conducting door-to-door assessment using the FSAC recommended tool. Markets assessments confirmed market functionality and available food, and prices are monitored. Based on cluster vulnerability criteria (household food stocks, current income, poor food consumption scores and use of more than one food-based emergency coping strategy), the most food insecure and vulnerable households will be identified by the BSCs, using the food consumption score card and rCSI. Selected beneficiaries will receive a token and will be fully informed about the assistance and how to access complaint and feedback systems, incl. Awaaz Afghanistan. Pre-distribution monitoring will be conducted as an extra verification to ensure eligibility of the beneficiaries and beneficiary lists will be shared with other actors for cross checking and avoidance of duplication. Cash will be provided through Hawala as dominated FSP in these districts. After each distribution, post distribution monitoring (PDM) will be conducted. PDMs will include questions related to risks associated with cash distribution. Cordaid/RRAA follow the FSAC guidelines for cash for food and the safer cash guidelines. Risk assessments for cash programming will be conducted and relevant risk mitigation measures will be taken to facilitate inclusive, safe and secure access of all beneficiaries (women, children, PWD, elderly) to cash assistance. Cordaid has tailored its response to a range of specific needs accounting for gender, age, disability, households headed by women, and families with specific protection needs. COVID-19 Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE) will be carried out as a cross cutting theme. Cordaid is committed to the Grand Bargain: in addition to participation, the use of cash and transparency (ReportHub IATI), Cordaid implements jointly with RRAA as part of its localization efforts and will strengthen RRAA’s capacity through training, coaching and funding

title.narrative: Emergency Food Security assistance to food insecure families in Achin and Mohmandara districts of Nangarhar province

description.narrative: The project will provide emergency response to the most vulnerable households (HHs) in Nangarhar who are food insecure as they are living under the poverty line and were already struggling to manage their minimum essential food needs, it is worsened by the loss of income/earning opportunity and thus purchasing power, as a result of COVID-19 pandemic in Afghanistan. The beneficiaries of this project are also living in recently cleared districts that are facing degraded food security situation due to long exposure to conflict. The most vulnerable people are included, specifically female headed HH, and HH with PWD and or where the primary breadwinner has lost their employment due to COVID-19. Through the proposed project Oxfam and long-term strategic partner Organization for Human Welfare (OHW) will provide cash assistance to a total of 15,000 individuals (2143 HHs) in Achin and Mohmandara districts of Nangarhar province to buy food items/commodities - these districts were recently cleared by Afghan National Forces from existence of ISIS. Based on the cluster standards and the allocation strategy paper, every eligible beneficiary HHs (those who experienced multiple resilience eroding shock in the past 6 months, and those subject to recent COVID-19 pressures, including lack of employment). they will receive half basket cash for food for 2 months (USD 90 for a period of 2 months in local currency) in one off. Cash for Food was preferred by the majority of the persons interviewed during the needs assessment since the local markets are operational. The Market Assessment confirmed that access is available and there is no restriction for both male and female while accessing/approaching market. The assessment revealed that, 40% of respondents identified cash, 18% preferred food, 6% education, 6% shelter, 25% WASH, and the rest of the 5% health facilities as first priorities. Similarly, 15% identified food, 27% cash, 25% preferred education, 11% preferred health facilities, 4% preferred shelter, and the rest 5% preferred WASH as second priorities. Oxfam’s interventions will be guided by the Integrated Food-Security Phase Classification (IPC) and Seasonal Food Security Assessment (SFSA) findings. As per IPC 2020 and SFSA, Nangarhar province was already in Crisis Situation (IPC3). Around 46% of the population in Nangarhar (1,237,262 individuals) were estimated to be at IPC3 or above during the period of April-May 2020 and 40% of the population (559,938 individuals) were estimated to be at IPC3 or above during the projection period June to November 2020. This project will support the most food-insecure population/communities in rural areas of Nangarhar Province, Achin and Mohmandara districts. FSAC identified that communities affected by COVID-19 are among the worst hit in terms of food insecurity. This project will target them so that they can survive without adopting harmful coping strategies and reduce their risk of exposure to the further shocks and build their resilience. A beneficiary selection committee using a weighted vulnerability score will be set up and also mention that post distribution monitoring (PDM) will be conducted and will include questions related to risks associated with cash distribution and efforts made to facilitate inclusive, safe and secure access of all beneficiaries (women, children, PWD, elderly) to cash assistance. COVID-19 Awareness raising messages developed by Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) with the support of World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF in the languages of Afghanistan will be used for this purpose. Oxfam will integrate conflict sensitivity into the action, by conducting context and conflict analysis of the target areas. This is especially important as cash assistance can work as potential flashpoint in creating new conflict or exacerbating existing tensions. The grant of USD 300,000 will provide immediate response and save lives of 15,000 persons (USD 20 per person).

The project will provide emergency response to the potentially vulnerable household (HHS) in Arghistan, Nesh, and Miwand districts of Kandahar province who are food insecure as they are living under the poverty line and experienced various multiple resilience eroding shock in the past six (6) months, and those subject to recent COVID-19 pressured, including loss of employment. .The COVID-19 lockdown and crisis have resulted in a serious and sustained impact on Kandahar and all Afghanistan’s economy. COVID-19 awareness-raising messages developed by the Ministry of Public health (MoPH) with support of the World Health Organization and UNICEF in the local languages.

description.narrative: The areas targeted under this project already had protection concerns and that has significantly increased in the COVID-19 pandemic situation and associated lockdown. Oxfam aims to assist 38,320 individuals (15,328 women, 11,496 men, 7664 girls and 3832 boys) who are severely affected by conflicts, flood, drought and Covid-19, by providing protection and Gender Based Violence (GBV) services which include a multisector response (legal, safety, health and psychosocial) through door-to door outreach and referrals that facilitate community based specialized services. description.narrative:
The project is aimed to provide (1) essential emergency health services consisting of trauma care and COVID-19 response in high priority areas of the three eastern provinces – Nangarhar, Kunar and Laghman and (2) essential protection and COVID-19 response services in Kunduz, Baghlan and Kapisa provinces. All of the target provinces are hard-hit by the current COVID-19 outbreak, and the security situation in all provinces have negatively impacted people’s access to services. In the three eastern provinces (Nangarhar, Kunar and Laghman), the primary focus of the project will be to make available trauma care services through the existing BPHS health facilities and to strengthen the uptake and management capacity of Nangarhar Regional Hospital (NRH) which is the main tertiary level facility in the eastern province. The trauma care services will be in the form of First Aid Trauma Posts (FATPs) established in the following health facilities. Kunar province: - Noorgal CHC (Noorgal district) - Saw PHC (Narai district) Laghman province: - Dawlat Shah CHC (Dawlat Shah district) - Alokhail BHC (Alingar district) In the three eastern provinces, the COVID-19 response services will be provided through the establishment and operation of COVID-19 MHPSS Outreach Teams tasked with two major objectives: (1) to provide mental health and psychosocial support services (MHPSS) to IDPs, host communities and shock-affected non-displaced communities and (2) to carry out risk communication and community engagement (RCCE) activities in line with the RCCE WG list of activities. A total of 5 COVID-19 MHPSS Outreach Teams will provide the mentioned services with specific geographical assignment as below: - Kunar Team-1 covering Noorgal and Khas Kunar districts - Kunar Team-2 covering Chawkai and Narang districts - Kunar Team-3 covering Asadabad, Watapur, and Sarkani districts - Laghman Team-1 covering Mehtherlam/Badpakh districts - Laghman Team-2 covering Alingar and Qarghayee districts
In the provinces of Kunduz, Baghlan and Kapisa, the modality of protection services provision will consist of the PSS and RCCE services provided through the planned 8 PSS Outreach Teams, and the remote telephonic consultations by experienced psychosocial counselors (PSCs) stationed in Kunduz (2 PSCs covering Kunduz and Baghlan provinces) and Mahmood-e-Raqi cities (2 PSCs covering Kapisa province). Secondly, general awareness of people in the three provinces will be raised through COVID-19 focused TV and radio spots in view of standard MoPH messages. Further, stress management to BPHS and EPHS health facilities staff in the three provinces will be an integral part of the project.
The health-related activities in three eastern provinces (Nangarhar, Kunar and Laghman) will be for 12 months, while the protection-related activities in Kunduz, Baghlan and Kapisa will be for 6 months.

title.narrative: Enhancing access to quality health care services for vulnerable communities in five provinces

description.narrative:
The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) is the world's largest humanitarian organization, with 192 member National Societies. As part of the International Red Cross and Red Crescent Movement, our work is guided by seven fundamental principles: humanity, impartiality, neutrality, independence, voluntary service, unity and universality.
IFRC Country Office, which enjoys a status agreement in Afghanistan, supports Afghan Red Crescent Society (ARCS) in strengthening its capacities and implementing programs and operations across the country. ARCS is “working with people that no one else can reach” as per its Strategic Plan 2016-2020 and within a new legal framework: The Law for the regulation of the ARCS Affairs.
Health is a set of core programs and services of ARCS aimed to contribute in strengthening the primary health care in the country. title.narrative: Inclusive COVID-19 Emergency WASH Response in Hard-to-Reach Areas of Badakhshan and Kunduz

description.narrative:
In Afghanistan, the pandemic comes at a time when the country is grappling with deadly conflict, severe food insecurity, and a dire economy that has plunged over 80% of the population below the poverty line (C-19 MSHCP). Existing WASH services including water and sanitation facilities were already unable to adequately support escalating WASH needs from conflict and natural disasters, without the added burden of COVID-19. According to IOM, the number of confirmed cases suggests that Afghanistan could have one of the highest infection rates in the world, with the Ministry of Public Health projecting over 25.6 million Afghans will be infected with the virus if serious action is not undertaken. With over 60% of COVID-19 tests allocated to just three of the country’s 34 provinces, humanitarian agencies continue to voice a lack of attention and support to other increasingly vulnerable areas. Accordingly, Kunduz and Badakhshan Provinces―the proposed area of intervention―have largely been neglected in terms of both testing and response, with 1,040 confirmed cases considered a severe underrepresentation of the current context (MoPH, 9/15/20). The lack of confirmed cases combined with rumors and limited access to reliable information have created a false sense of security, prompting communities to disregard vital prevention measures required to mitigate or reduce the likelihood of an outbreak.
Through a whole of community approach, Concern Worldwide is proposing inclusive and accessible COVID-19 emergency response in underserved, hard-to-reach areas of Yaftal and Arghanch Khwa districts of Badakhshan and Khanabad and Aliabad districts of Kunduz, entailing: 1) the installation of age, gender, and disability-inclusive handwashing stations at remote health care facilities and public gathering areas 2) the rehabilitation of damaged village hand pump wells that are safe and accessible to different vulnerability groups and 3) the targeted construction of safe and appropriate latrines for disabled and female-headed households. Specifically, Concern will install 960 communal handwashing stations at pre-identified vulnerable sites of target communities, taking into consideration age, gender, and disability access to ensure equal assistance. This includes sex-segregated facilities (where applicable), soak pits for water drainage, and an appropriate height for comfortable access and use by children, elderly, and people with a disability. Handwashing stations will be provided alongside a three-month supply of liquid soap, and will require the signing of an MoU that details sustained community-led maintenance and management, including proper transportation and storage of water. Additionally, through a community-based participatory approach, Concern will identify and rehabilitate 80 damaged hand pump wells that are accessible and safe for the whole community in order to address the prevalent lack of access to clean water. Existing CBOs, community leaders, and representatives of MRRD will be involved in the site selection process to ensure local buy-in and sustainability of the repaired infrastructure. Guided by inclusive Beneficiary Selection Committees (BSCs), Concern will identify 415 disabled and female-headed households that lack able-bodied members for the construction of sanitary latrines. Concern will abide by UNHCR’s protection checklist for sanitation facilities, including a safe location, proper lighting, minimum space standards, and locks on the inside for privacy and safety. Throughout project implementation, Concern will mainstream COVID-19 risk communication and awareness campaigns, including gender-sensitive hygiene promotion, rumor management, contextual mitigation measures, and available channels for health support. The timely provision of the WASH minimum package will establish the conditions that allow 63,720 people to live with good health, dignity, and comfort―which is particularly crucial in the context of a pandemic.

title.narrative: Procurement and Prepositioning of Core Supplies for WASH Response

description.narrative:
The COVID 19 Pandemic has significantly affected Afghanistan due to its weak health system and limited capacity to prevent the spread of the virus. High internal displacement and a weak water and sanitation infrastructure worsen the situation. A new wave of the virus feared to come during the winter of 2020 could add significantly to the agony of an Afghan population already grappling with the economic impact of the virus. According to the Afghanistan Humanitarian Response Plan (June 2020 update) as many as 35 million Afghans are in need of a social safety net, 14 million people are in need of humanitarian assistance, while 7.2 million of those are in need of water, sanitation and hygiene assistance specifically.
DACAAR directly contributes to this plan and to the containment of the COVID-19 outbreak as well as to improving the overall WASH condition of at risk populations by procuring, prepositioning and making available handwashing soap as a core WASH pipeline supply in support of WASH Cluster partner response projects.
Handwashing with soap is considered as one of the most effective containment strategies for COVID 19 available to at risk populations. Procuring and supplying soap as a standalone hygiene item will be swift and will add to the agility of response by WASH partners. Given that this is a stockpiling project and the distribution of the supplies will be undertaken by other WASH partners, the target beneficiaries will not be assisted by DACAAR but by partners. DACAAR will report on the beneficiaries based on reports from WASH partners who accessed the stockpiles. Distribution by WASH partners to at risk families will be based on the Sphere Standard of a minimum of 250grams of soap per person per month. DACAAR will procure and preposition 651,000 bars of 130gram high quality anti-septic soap sufficient for 3 months use for 15,500 at risk families (108,500 individuals).
The soap supplies will be stocked in the following strategic geographical hubs: Kabul, Kandahar city Herat city Mazar-e-Sharif city Kunduz city Maimana city (Faryab) and in Talugan city (Takhar), with the potential of being moved to locations where need is greatest. These locations are central enough to be accessed by partners implementing WASH projects in the provinces prioritized in the AHF 5th reserve allocation strategy namely Badghis, Herat, Faryab, Zabul, Badakhshan, Nimroz, Kunduz and Jawzjan as well as from other provinces of the country. DACAAR will maintain sufficient flexibility to transfer supplies among the warehouses. Partners can readily access available stock of soap for use in their response projects based on approval from the WASH Cluster.
Procurement of the soap will be performed as part of a comprehensive Invitation to Bed (ITB) process following DACAAR procurement procedures (attached) which is line with AHF procurement regulations. The ITB process will include a market assessment enabling DACAAR to identify and contract the cheapest bidder who can deliver the highest quality soap. Procured soap will be checked stringently to ensure highest anti-septic quality (given recent lessons learned from the sector on fake Dettol soap in the market). The following will be performed during the ITB to ensure quality of soap procured - Physical Description : - Based on experience and technical knowhow , the assigned technical colleagues know the physical attribute of the quality soap required and check the delivered soap accordingly.
- Industrial Standards Certificate/ Proving Documents: - The bidders are usually asked for the required documents. A Sample is attached.
- Legal Import: - DACAAR buys legally imported Antiseptic Dettol Soap having proper custom clearance documents.
In addition to the above, DACAAR will reserve the right to perform laboratory examiniation of the soap with the help of Afghanistan National Standards Authority (ANSA).

Children and women are one of the most vulnerable categories in the upcoming winter season who are detrimentally impacted by the livelihood crisis worsened by the COVID-19 pandemic which compounds the vulnerabilities arising from protracted conflict in Afghanistan. Children in Crisis is requesting $250K to mount a rapid response to mitigate and respond to the protection risks related to the current crisis and to increase access to essential information, supplies and services for 16000 conflict and crisis-affected individuals across Badakhshan, Bamiyan, Kabul and Paktika provinces. Protection programmes will be implemented in Faizabad, Kishma Argo districts in Badakhshan, Bamyan, Shibar, Panjab, Yakawlang districts in Bamyan, Kabul, Paghman, Shakar Darah, Guldara, Istalif districts in Kabul and Sharan, Yousufkhail, Gomal and Barmal districts in Paktika. The project promotes the physical and psychosocial protection of vulnerable conflict and crisis-affected children and women during the upcoming winter season through (i) Case management services (which includes identification, intervention plan and referral services for children with vulnerabilities due to winter season and COVID-19 (ii) Establishment and training of community based protection committees to identify, respond to protection risks and incidents and refer and follow up for specific services and (iii) Provision of essential winterization kits. The strategic selection of these activities is intended to respond to protection risks of children in the immediate term compounded by the current crises, whilst building sustainable institutions to increase communities’ resilience to the long term, embedded protection risks for at risk children and the wider group of children. The project uses a scaffolded intervention that intensifies support and services across categories of increasing vulnerabilities: 2500 vulnerable households with more than four children, identified through vulnerability and needs assessment will receive essential life-saving winterization kits to support the children of households by providing warm clothes and blankets, that supports them to continue attending school, and interact with other children in public space during the winter season. 56 vulnerable communities shall benefit from the functional community based protection committees which shall be trained to mitigate and respond to protection risks of individuals and groups in the community 2900 vulnerable children (including children at significant risk: UASC, CAAFAG, street children, GBV survivors) shall benefit from the direct referrals and supplementary services provided by Children in Crisis. Specifically, 250 UASC children at significant risk due to separation from caregivers will receive counselling and case management services and 250 children at severe risk of exposure to exploitation and violence will receive specialized services including interim care, case management and family tracing and reunification.
Children in Crisis [CiC] is a protection sector specialist, recognized as one of the “Top Ten NGO” actors by the Child Protection Action Network [CPAN] in 2019. Our extensive experience and expertise in protection programming – with proven approaches to working with incarcerated children – positions us to implement an intensive intervention over a six-month project period. At present, CIC also operates an Education in Emergencies intervention targeting 3500 conflict-affected children in Uruzgan under the Afghanistan Humanitarian Fund approx. 20% of this intervention includes integrated protection activities that underscore our sustained commitment and capabilities in protection.

title.narrative: Comprehensive Winterisation Response in Underserved Communities of Kunduz and Takhar

description.narrative:
Due to the economic impact of COVID-19, an estimated 1.3 million Afghans will not have access to heating and fuel this winter, leaving them extremely vulnerable to below freezing temperatures (Joint Winterisation Strategy Afghanistan, 2020). In high altitude areas with cold climates and harsh weather conditions, lives are at risk within one day of exposure to the elements. Families may be pushed to employ negative coping mechanisms, which can often have serious protection implications for women and children.
In response, Concern Worldwide is proposing urgent and time-sensitive winterisation assistance to address the severe NFI needs of acutely vulnerable host, IDPs and returnee populations of Kunduz and Takhar provinces. The proposed target districts―Namakab and Chal of Takhar and Aqtash of Kunduz―were identified based on the agency’s demonstrated operational capacity and access, coordination with other humanitarian actors in the area, severity of winterisation needs, and lack of previous assistance. Specifically, Concern is prepared to respond to the critical NFI needs of 959 acutely vulnerable families with a comprehensive winterisation package of i) 3-month heating/fuel cash assistance ($200 per family) ii) in-kind standard blanket packages ($40 value per family) and iii) in-kind winter clothing kits ($65 value per family). The use of cash for heating and fuel support, backed by recent market assessments, PDMs, and REACH evaluations, provides families with the flexibility to purchase the most appropriate appliances for their specific shelter type. This includes a gas cylinder or Bukhari stove and 180 Kg of firewood or LPG. The provision of in-kind blanket packages and winter clothing kits will keep the immediate space around bodies warm, and significantly help vulnerable families cope with the winter season. While these items are intended to be distributed jointly, households that do not meet the criteria for all three packages will only receive the relevant assistance. Given the time-sensitive nature of this response, with winter quickly approaching, Concern will distribute the mentioned support via a single instalment.
During assessments and distributions, Concern will mainstream COVID-19 risk communication and awareness campaigns―including COVID-19 kits and hygiene promotion within winter sectorial response―as well as gender-sensitive behavioral change messaging to positively influence expenditure choices and coping strategies. Since the distribution is conducted in an closed space during winter, Concern will ensure to limit the number of beneficiaries per distribution and will provide masks to beneficiaries as well as project staff. Sanitizers will be procured to utilize by the beneficiaries and staff during the distribution. Gender, age, and disability considerations will be integrated as much as possible to ensure the response is inclusive to all segments of a community, particularly People with Specific Needs (PSNs). Winterisation response will place special attention towards children, the elderly, chronically ill, or those with limited mobility to deliver lifesaving insulation support to the most at-risk groups.
